captions.text:
That so?
How do you know that?
How you sure?

Only one way to find out,
dude. Let's go.

Yeah. I'm not feeling
so good right now.

Seriously,
my skin hurts!

Enough from
the peanut gallery!

Into the water,
ladies!

No, no, no, man. Let me
take a look at that map
right quick.

Why is everybody
all obsessed with the map?

'cause we're tired
of being your trail donkeys!

Acting like you
some one-man gps!

God damn it! We lost!
We fucking super lost, man!

Tell him, mcclusky.
Tell him what time it is.

I don't believe
you people.

What do you mean,
"you people"?

What do you mean,
"you people"?

I think what
tugg means is...

No, look at
his eyes, man.

...You people, you
actors. You people...

Look at them
beady, white devil eyes.

I gotta get
back to the hotel,
for real!
Oh, hell, no!

(machine gun firing)
silence!

Chill! All right?
Just chill it.

Now, let's go get
those viet congs.

"viet cong"!
What?

You wouldn't say
"chineses."

All right, that's enough
of this insubordination!

If the machine
breaks down,
we break down.

And then  <i>rambo ii,</i>
<i>he got all shredded up?</i>

Yeah.
That's kind of how
you look right now.
Oh...

Yeah?
Not  <i>rambo I</i> but  <i>ii.</i>

Really?
Yeah, when
he was cut up.

I'm not that... I mean,
that's what I'm going for,
but you know...

Come on, dude.
You more shredded
than a julienne salad, man.

Thanks.
What's the secret, dude?

It's a diet.
I'm just dieting.
Really?

'cause I'm trying
to come up a little,
but it's just... It's tough.

You look good.
Any tips?

What?
Any tips, you got?

There's, like,
the pineapple...

Give me
that goddamn map!
Hey!
Fuck you!

Hey!
All right, now!

What it is,
sikorski?

Tell us where
we really at.

That's fucking bullshit!
It's a chump move.

We just getting
a second opinion, doc.
(groaning)

We're going
the wrong way!

Damn!
Son of a bitch.

God! I think
we were supposed
to be doing this,

And instead
we did this.

Shit, shit,
shit, shitty shit, shit!

Think you can get us back
to that drop zone, boy?

Maybe.

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure that this wisdom is delivered by a man in blackface who has 
gone to similarly near-insane levels of method acting is an entirely 
deliberate irony.

The whole movie is about the absurdity of Hollywood and the lengths they 
will go to trying to act like they're pushing boundaries while remaining on 
the safest bets possible, and the point of this scene is that accurately 
portrayed people with mental disabilities aren't fun to watch- but 
audiences love relatable yet disadvantaged people with extraordinary 
talents to make up for it.﻿

comments.author: G Da Silva (BluByte)

comments.text:
+Quaxo123
Except you're a White girl telling us Black folks how to react. No, it 
isn't racist and the vast majority of Blacks don't find it racist. 

"doesn't see blackface as an issue."

It's not an issue because it's not Black face. 

"I stepped on your foot to show you how bad it would be if I stepped on 
your foot! But it's okay because I'm not really stepping on it, I'm just 
showing how funny it would be if I did!"

Your analogy fails because even if we were to assume that these were indeed 
satirical depictions of a man playing black face with the intention to mock 
it, harm is never translated in satire, while literally stepping on 
someone's foot is the root cause of pain. Talking about racial stereotypes 
or even depicting them with the intent to show how flawed they are is NOT 
the root of the problem, racism is. Stepping on someone's foot is the root 
cause of the problem. A good analogy would be if I made a movie showing 
what would happen if I stepped on your foot, without actually stepping on 
your foot.  ﻿
comments.author: Thurman Ulrich

comments.text:
Don't you guys understand, that the reason why RDJ was casted for this part 
was to mock the very idea of Black-Face? The actual black character in the 
movie even mocks him! The reason why the character is so animated, 
hammed-up, and exaggerated is to mock the practise of casting white actors 
for colored characters, back when it was a regular practise during the 
early hollywood period.

Apparently, that was "subtle" for some slow individuals, who couldn't catch 
onto the use of lampooning and satire. Jeez guys, perhaps dissect and 
inspect certain plot devices, or satirical tones before playing the racism 
card? Fuck's sake you idiots.  ﻿

comments.author: Kinghellblood

comments.text:
I cannot believe that people, both black & white (other ethnic people 
taking potshots also) - are actually considering Robert Downey Jr. a 
'racist'
 for playing the absurdity of an Australian Actor playing an 
African-American soldier for the sole reason of demonstrating the 
ridiculousness that the movie successfully portrayed; it was a movie that 
pushed buttons in hilarious ways, from Ben Stiller's character playing 
'Simple Jack', and constantly talking in terms of 
moron/retard/imbecilic/etc. to Robert Downey playing an Australian actor 
hired to play a black soldier in such a silly, innocuous fashion, and may I 
add - in the funniest shit I've seen displayed. The 'real' black guy plays 
a closet homosexual, Jack Black plays the white-trash 'heroin addicted 
junkie', and so forth.
The movie was meant to illustrate all those elements and controversial 
aspects of the actors beyond the characters who are all on their last limb 
standing and attempting to save their careers in the most absurd ways as 
demonstrations of impressive performances. It is a terrific comedy, one of 
my favorites, and for those who can only concentrate on Robert Downey Jr. 
as playing a 'black African-American soldier', who is in the script of the 
movie is an Australian, Blonde haired/blue-eyed Australian, and actually 
considers the move racist or Robert Downey Jr. 'racist', is more ludicrous 
and insane than the movie's comedic portrayal itself. How sensitive do we 
have to be to certain groups? You telling me that HORRID movie 'White 
Chicks', where a couple of black actors (barely) play two white females 
with extensive, and unconvincing - TRULY unconvincing - make-up and 
prosthetics & who acted like 'typical stupid white girls', right? 
Yet Robert Downey Jr. is a racist, where these two horrible actors are were 
unassailable... why? Because whites can 'only be racist' is the sad 
misinformation of the nature of racist individuals and the generalization 
of racism in groups.
If the movie is racist, then it's also insensitive to the 'mentally 
challenged', it is insensitive to those suffering from 'substance abuse', 
it is insensitive to 'homophobia', it is a travesty to all morality... LOL. 
Yeah, thank God I am not a thin-skinned white person, living in Toronto, in 
a predominantly black area, I let racist 'white boy', 'cracker', 'ghost', 
'powder boy' etc. comments bounce right off my back - thank God, because I 
have met four extremely wonderful people that have become fast-friends, an 
Algerian, Jamaican, and two South Americans, and they are cool, open, 
intelligent, and yes my two South African friends laughed their asses off 
during 'Tropical Thunder'. They are understand what is comedy and what is 
aggressive authentic racism.
Anyway, for those who cannot comprehend the difference between 
hyperbolic-exaggerative comedy and truly real 'racist' motivation - then 
you people (black & white & everything between) are very clueless and 
aimlessly lash-out in living in a constructed reality of being permanently 
offended by every single aspect in every single situation without the 
intellectualism to determine what is sincerely a 'threat or clear insult to 
a certain ethnicity or colour or skin' or what is an exaggeration into the 
comedic world which should be taken as a 'foolish, hilarious, & unserious' 
foray into comedy.
Educate yourself, all of you, before deciding that Robert Downey Jr. is 
'racist' - more idiotic than anything I have heard in a very long time - or 
if his 'scripted character' is a racist intent by the 'movie production 
itself'; equally in stupidity. It is actually scary that certain black 
friends of the U.S.A. and Canada can construe this movie, this Robert 
Downey Jr. character inclusion, as 'irrefutable racism'. It is actually a 
sad comment - not towards the movie, or Robert Downey Jr., but is a sad 
statement about many thin-skinned people in the black communities across 
the U.S. & Canada, & potentially some pockets around the world.
*Tropical Thunder* is a brilliantly funny movie, both hilarious and 
action-packed, both confusingly subtle and outrageous & detailed to the 
core of the characters they developed for this movie production. 'Race' (as 
there is no 'race' in the human race because it is simply genetically, 
factually properly named the 'Human Race') does not even spark a thought of 
racism in my mind, nor arises any offending nature from my closest South 
African dark-coloured skin friends - because they find humour rather than 
offending wisps of racial discrepancies. Then again they are intelligent 
and 'get' the movie. More that can be said for some of you thin-skinned 
permanently offended silly fools!
Great, hilarious performance, Robert Downey Jr. It was the *Best Part Of 
This Movie*! ; ) ﻿

comments.text:
lol you should look up the word satire. It's hilarious and poignant on many 
levels...and they address it head on several times if you see the whole 
movie...for instance when Alpa refers to downey as "chicken george"...the 
first joke is at Russell Crowe's expense thus the australian actor who 
submerges themself into the character they are playing....downey is such a 
pure actor he "had to go black" literally...then they also address it again 
when Alpa talks about how there was only one role for a black guy and it 
went to the australian white actor....referring to Hollywood's constant 
racial blunder's like on the God of Egypt movie where the main egyptian 
characters are white ppl with bronzer on...this is not a case of black face 
being used as a racial negative...if anything Alpa was the true negative 
stero type....slinging booty sweat and bust a nut....hit song I love the 
pussy....a true archetype of modern hip hop and its woes...satirical 
comedies like this are more than the surface.
